Having played 92.8 Hours of this game I will share my thoughts on what this game does right, and what it does wrong.

I will say playing this game solo is a much better experience than playing multiplayer, unless you plan on having separate bases. The loot does not appear to increase alongside the number of players, so you and your friend will be fighting over the already low amount of items you have to take care of yourself. 

With that out of the way, the majority of my hours are single player so I will review in that regard as the only multiplayer specific problem is what i shared above.

Subsistence is a survival game that truly feels like one to me. Don't get me wrong I LOVE the forest and other survival titles that have risen to popularity over recent years - but usually the survival aspect is secondary and not usually challenging unless you play on the hardest difficulty. 
That being said what you do in this game is exactly as the title says. You subsist. Some other reviewers have a large problem with this, but I think it is what makes this game unique compared to other survival games. You will not be fully kitted within a day of playing. You may not even have a finished base with all walls and ceilings after a day of playing. You are not OP in this game. Many gamers like to just be god, and if that's your thing this game is not for you.

Pros:
- PVE Combat is a really unique aspect of this game introducing "hunters" that move into your world and try to destroy your base and you can raid their base for more loot. I've always wanted a game like rust that is strictly PVE, so theres no need to worry about cheaters or someone offline raiding your base etc.
- There are a lot of unique energy management systems in this game which makes the player decide how they will manage the power of their base. Will you keep the fridge running? Or will you install lights in your base so its not so dark? ETC
- In order to receive good loot you need to work for it. This is not the type of game where you can get lucky and find god items in a crate off of the spawn.
- The game wants to encourage exploration by only allowing certain resources to be gathered from certain places. This means you will have to leave your base consistently if you want to progress.
- You easily get your 14$ worth if you are a fan of survival games and you follow the 1$ / an hour of gameplay rule.
- Every fight you get into is somewhat challenging (even with the animals, some can outrun you)
- The building is fun, there are a lot of ways to make your base look nice geometrically so you dont live in a cube. (You can if youd like, though)

Things that could be PROS or CONS depending on perspective:
- This game is made by a solo developer I believe, which given that - the game is still being updated after all these years and clearly is a passion project from the dev. Hats off. This might not be for you however if you want consistent and steady updates.
- This game is very grind heavy. Your resources get swallowed up fast if you are not consistently going out and getting more. To many this makes the game have "fake gameplay" where you are given busy work disguised as gameplay. If you want to chop down 3 trees and have enough wood for the rest of your world this is not the game for you. You are subsisting, and constantly trying to stay afloat. I have this listed under pros and cons because once you get into a rhythm this gets a lot better than when you are first starting off in a world.
- Progression is slow. This follows the above statement in that you will always have something to work towards because you need to save up resources over the course of many days to craft the one machine you wanted to make.
- The Looting system. There are randomized crate spawn locations all around the map that come in the form of food crates, ammo crates, medical crates, construction crates, and locked crates (with goodies inside). This is the only way to get certain materials reliably. You either love this or you hate it.
- The animal spawns are insane, you are constantly running into wolves and bears and you better hope you came prepared if they start chasing you and you have no stamina. 

CONS:
- Gun play is extremely clunky. Never try to hit a moving target, your bullet will not land 95% of the time.
- The Winter season is incredibly devoid of content to make it fun. I constantly switch my season back to spring when winter rolls around just so I have something to do. (You can easily do this from the main menu when selecting your world)
- Many of the machines you make have very few purposes (very specialized, they do 1 thing and 1 thing well).
- Multiplayer resources are not doubled, you and your friends will be suiciding to increase hunger meter / stamina etc.

And down to some minor complaints
- Blood does not wash off your hands when it rains, but if you go swimming it will.
- It took me a while to realize that when you die you lose a little bit of everything you have in your inventory, the game does not tell you this in an obvious way (That I know of)
- Would be nice to have more options when it comes to upgrading your base to metal, as both the wood AND the metal textures feel very rough. Would be cool if there were a decor update or something of the sort, just to spruce things up a bit.
- Beds cost power to respawn you at your base. I believe this is to prevent your base from being a safe haven, but why not just put a respawn delay on it? (You can only spawn at the bed every 15 IRL minutes).
- Its nearly impossible to get out of the water after swimming/diving.

CONCLUSION:
I think this game is worth exactly what the developer charges. Its 14$, which is what many people would spend at a restaurant or the movies. It is easily 14h worth of entertainment if you enjoy survival games. It is goofy, and it is a little clunky at times, but for a single developer this is some really good work. You eventually learn how to play along with the quirks as you would any other game (see: source engine movement tech, etc). Maybe the real subsisting was the friends we made along the way.

[i]Please keep in mind, this game is made by one person. My review tries to be objective despite that, but I also feel the need to mention it.[/i]

This is the single player crafting / survival game you've been wanting. Rough and incomplete, but playable and fun.

[b]Graphics:[/b] 7
There's a strange imbalance (so far) with the visual fidelity of this game. The bases and related assets all look great. Very detailed and blends great with the interior lighting. The environment is solid, but basic and dated looking, as with the animals. However, there have been great improves via updates over the last year, and I know the developer is constantly looking to improve it as much as he can.

[b]Sound:[/b] 6
Basic, but doable. Unfortunately, when you're developing a game, you have to prioritize what you work on first, and sound is usually more of a placeholder until the other things like graphics, performance, and balance is worked out. I will say there are a number of sound effects that are really unique to this game specifically and adds to the atmosphere. I think once music is added, it will really push the sound into a 7 or 8 at that point.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] 8
The game is pretty tedious at first, but once you actually establish a base and start adding to it, the game picks up and becomes really fun. I think item collection and crafting needs to be sped up, though. It's still too slow for being a single player game.

[b]Performance:[/b] 7
Solid performance, but drops on most systems if everything is maxed out. Optimization is not usually a priority for an early access game, so that's forgivable at this point.

[b]Final Thoughts[/b]
If you're coming from a fully fleshed out survival / crafting / PVP game like Rust, you're going to have a bad time. Rust has been an ongoing project for almost a decade. It has a team of developers behind it, it makes a substantial amount of money (almost never falling off the top 10 most popular games), and has thousands of volunteers and contributors.

One guy makes this game. That's it. One. Even by himself, he pumps out updates on a regular basis. He listens to feedback and implements suggestions to see if they work. Although it does have co-op, it primarily focuses around single player survival and crafting, which is almost unheard of in this day and age. I've heard thousands of people beg the Rust developers for an offline mode with bots. They won't do it. That is what this guy is trying to achieve, and doing a fantastic job considering his extremely limited resources.

I have over a thousand hours in Rust, yet this game draws me in and keeps me playing. I always look forward to the next update, because I have yet to be disappointed. I'll admit the game isn't for everyone, but stop calling this game trash when you all drop $60 on AAA games that nickel and dime you to death for content that was supposed to be included for the base price, then dumping the game after 3 months and buying another $60 con-job title. If you want actual good games, made by actual passionate developers who listen to their players, then support them.

[b]TL;DR[/b]
If you want multiplayer crafting / survival / PvP, play Rust. If you want a true single player version, buy this game.

108142255.review:
Typically, I stay away from early-access titles, especially recommending them, as they generally become stagnant or dead by developers who have no incentive to finish their product because they've already gotten our money. However, I am willing to make an exception for this game. Before I get into my reasoning for this, let me tell you my likes, dislikes, concerns, and recommendations for this game.

Likes:
Environment- There is currently only one map to play on at the moment, but it is large enough that I don't feel caged in (even though you literally are). The changing seasons is something unique that a lot of games don't bother to add and it’s not just a passive scenery change. The seasons and weather are an actual factor against your survival. Hot summer days fatigue and dehydrate you, where taking a dip in the lake to cool off is a must. Brutal winter blizzards that produce white-out conditions and drop the temperature to deathly lows. Even altitude plays a factor, where the higher you travel up the mountain, the colder it gets. Another factor that I like (though some may not) is that the environment is indestructible, so trees, rocks, the ground, etc. are all permanent. This prevents the map being deforested or obnoxious mining pits and other “holes” in the map that inevitably take place on other crafting games. This keeps the amazing views and scenery fresh and untouched for all to enjoy.

Base Construction- Keeping in mind that the environment is indestructible, it is impossible to smooth out a patch of terrain to start laying down a foundation. This is not a problem, as the game allows you to clip all building pieces into the surrounding barriers, so that you can truly build anywhere, even to a fault. You can build floating bases over water, or even in the sky (although ColdGames is currently working on structural integrity to eliminate the unrealistic building potential). Once you have the main foundation pieces down, they become the parent pieces, which everything else snaps to. On the inside of your base, adding storage chests, work benches, and any other utilities can be freely moved around without snaps, and even clipped through other items in some circumstances. There are enough pieces present to make some truly varying and unique builds, if you have the dedication to grinding for the materials.

Survival- Surviving in this game truly feels like an accomplishment. You can even passively compare your “survival” stats with anyone else on the server who is online. Things like how many times you have died, how many animals you have killed, all the way down to how many logs you have harvest, are all stats that you and other players can see about each other. With all of the things the environment throws at you, along with how scarce everything is, you really do feel rewarded for surviving several in-game weeks or months (or even years if you’re good) without dying. If you choose the male avatar, he even starts growing a beard the longer you live.

Dislikes:
AI- The AI in this game definitely leaves something to be desired, specifically the hunters, rogues, and miners (all human AI). The animals are acceptable, but not great. Depending on the difficulty, the human AI are either painfully inept, or frustratingly god-like, and sometimes both at the same time. They have infinite ammo with near perfect accuracy, while you are forced to suffer through maintaining just enough ammo to hunt for a day or two. Worse, when you kill them, they MAYBE drop a bullet or two, but generally nothing useful to make them worth killing other than defending yourself.

Gunplay- I’m going to be brutally honest, the gunplay in this game is bad. There is no way around it. The game is built with a hitbox system that is terrible in its’ current state, bullets that travel like airsoft BBs, and damage stats that are more on the level of counter-strike, requiring multiple headshots to kill hunters and animals alike, depending on the weapon you’re using. This game would really be a step up with a more tactical-hardcore approach to the gunplay.

Looting/Crafting essentials- As many others have stated, regardless of how many hours you invest in building a fortress and getting all of the “advanced” goodies for your base, the grind is still the same at any stage of the game. You will always be starving for cartridge cases, unless you just stick with the bow. If you just stick with the bow, you will always be starving for nails. There are ways to make these things for yourself, instead of looting them, but the material cost vs output is a total rip-off, which will leave you starving for other resources.

Concerns:
One of my biggest concerns is the lack of theme or cohesion with all of the in-game assets. Because there is only one person working on this game, I can understand and appreciate the use of the Unreal asset store, but at least pick assets that fit the same theme. The main rifle in the game is an SVT-40, a pretty rare WWII Russian battle rifle. The main handgun is an M9 Beretta, a fairly common “modern” 9mm pistol. The base tech is just plain weird, with antique stoves and refrigerators, but futuristic/sci-fi power and mass storage and drills and refineries. The distillery looks like some kind of steampunk concoction of 1800’s tech mixed with 2077 tech.

Not all vegetation yields seeds, or lets you extract seeds, making at least 50% or more of the plants in the game artificially scarce. The math doesn’t add up with certain craftables, requiring too much input for too little output. The cost to repair things is almost not worth it with the majority of base pieces and weapons, barely being better than just making new parts. Upgrades to base items is worth it, but very grindy. Weapons upgrades force you to use more and more valuable and scarce materials to keep it repaired. The decay rate of tools and weapons seems too high, especially on upgraded weapons.

Recommendations:
This game could benefit from some what I think are very minor fixes/tweaks. Firstly, the gunplay needs to be more realistic and hardcore. The survival in this game is hardcore, so the use of firearms should match that difficulty. Add multiple recipes for the same item, so that you aren’t bottlenecked by the ultra-rare materials. Let the player make stone-tipped arrows instead of wasting nails, when in the early game, nails are the biggest bottleneck. Make the material requirements for all items more plausible and realistic. I don’t know why I need pearls for circuit boards. I don’t know why I need sinew to craft high-tech base items. I don’t know why I need cloth to build a gun. Make the foundation legs terminate against any surface they clip with, so that they don’t float in space on the level below them. Pick a coherent theme and replace all of the assets with something that fits the theme.

I know this is a long review, but this is a game I am truly passionate about. As I stated at the beginning, I don’t usually partake in early-access titles, because they usually die with an incomplete product and a dev walking away with their pockets full. However, I truly believe that this dev cares about his game. His updates are infrequent, but meaningful. His efforts to make this a truly stand-out survival game are apparent. The game is solid enough to be played and acceptable as is. Notice I’m saying “his” a lot? Yea, there is literally only one guy responsible for all of this. For that, I commend his efforts and his responsiveness to the community and truly believe that what he is making is a great game. For that, I recommend this title to anyone who is willing to grind through the learning curve and who enjoys survival/crafting games.

TIPS & TRICKS:
It is a very hard game to master, but don't give up after only a few hours, as you WILL progress and you WILL enjoy the game as it does get "easier"

- Start on EASY, set the month to MAY and the year cycle to 365. (Can change anytime)

- Stay away from animals other than chickens and rabbits for the time being.

- Shift left clicking moves whole stacks to and from fires, storage, inventory etc

- Shift right click is single items.

- Press "F" when in inventory menu or any other menu to use items (food/water/splints/etc)

- Grab every crate you can find and get chopping wood (Its boring at first but you need plenty at the beginning.

- Craft while you are running around (wood-planks & wood to sticks & fibre-cordage)

- Craft a bow and keep a good amount of arrows handy as you'll need them for rabbits & chickens.

- Always aim lower with guns (Aim for the chin will usually get a headshot)

- Hunt rabbits and chickens each day (4-6 preferably) It's not ideal, but will do until your ready for wolves. Chickens can be caught without arrows, just chase and jump at them intil they run out of stamina. just watch where they are heading! 6 will give you a couple of meat for next day while your hunting. Just make sure to cook as late as possible so your meat stays fresh as long as possible for next day.

- Any ponds/lakes - dive for kelp to keep vegetables up until you start planting seeds (which can be found around the map). DON'T FORGET PEARLS WHILE YOU'RE DOWN THERE! You will need them like crazy later on.

- Big trees give you 6 wood and a grub (which can be used for fishing)

- Find a nice flat area (I recommend the green pasture inbetween both lakes on the map) as it is MUCH easier to spot crates, and there is a pond there for your kelp and pearls.

- Craft a fire and make cheap fire starter kits from BIOFUEL & sticks. Again, as many as possible, as the cheap fire goes out quick.

- Craft a wood foundation and a wall, stick the fire on the foundation (don't worry it won't burn your house down.

- Craft a storage crate and stick it near the wall and start hoarding loot!

- Retracing your steps is fine, as loot spawns in randomly (so an empty run one way can be full of loot on the way back)

- Rinse and repeat previous steps: collecting as many crates as possible and storing as much as you can (Don't forget to hunt 4-6 per day)

- BCU: Once placed, Hunters and Rogues will spawn within a few days. (So try not to place it until you have plenty of stock and a roof over your head). The BCU gives you the wood-burner which lasts much longer than campfires, so up to you as you need more firestarters for campfires going out.

- Hunters: There are 3 bases of them on easy and medium (alpha,bravo,charlie) small-large.
They will leave you alone as long as you stay away from them. They go fishing, hunting animals and chopping trees, so be aware if you hear anything. (make sure settings are revenge attack only! or off for now as you need to learn the basic mechanics.)

- Rogues: travel around the map and make campfires. Again, they will leave you alone unless you get in their way, so try to avoid them completely. (They drop gears, wood, fish and medicinal tonics)

- Animals: All can be outrun (provided you have enough stamina). They give up pretty easily, usually. They have two aggro prompts (low growl then a louder one). First one, if you stop and moe back slowly without running, they will leave you alone most of the time. Second one, they are moving in your direction, and when close enough will start to charge. Don't worry as they give up after a while.

- If you get bitten there is a chance of infection, lowering your stats significantly! You can cure with an antidote made from oil from fish crafted into medicinal tonics and kelp.

- You can take a shot at wolves and other animals and run. They will chase you, but eventually slow down and give up. Turn around and hit them again. Rinse & repeat.

- BCU recharges 500 energy and 100 mass for free each day, so save your biofuel early on.

- BCU FIRST ITEMS TO GET: woodburner-generator-refinery-lockpicks-workbench.
- Woodburner can cook 3 items at once and melt down fat into biofuel for generator. Lasts much longer than campfire.

- Refinery: smelt down as much as you can

- Lockpicks: useful! they cost 18 iron fragments (from smelting ore in refinery) 4 metal scrap and 2 wood planks. Quite expensive! But when you find a locked crate, many times you'll find some high end materials that can help you out early on.

- Workbench allows you to upgrade your weapons to do much more damage amongst many other great tools.

- Plant beds: Get one and plant as many cotton seeds as you find, constantly! and other vegetables to help with your overall wellness. 

- Power & Mass storage: Your base generates 500 power and 100 mass for free each day, but for many of the other recipes you will need more. Craft one here and there and store in a safe place to avoid damage from revenge attacks from hunters.

- Solar panels & Wind turbines: EXPENSIVE! but just make one here and there when you can, as they slowly (VERY SLOWLY) start to increase your power input the more you have. Eventually you can run fridges, mining drills, grow lights etc without losing power if you have enough. It takes a long time though, so just keep an eye on your input and output.

- Always have your generator on while using refinery and other power draining tools, until you have enough energy coming in to run without.

- upgrade power efficiency on mining drills, refinery, fridge, oven etc.

- Don't upgrade solar panels or wind turbines. It's better to just get more of them cost wise.

That's about all I can think of for now anyway. I hope this helps!

I have played a long solo single player game for more than 100 hours and I have finished building a small base, have tons of food. Power, Water are no longer an issue. Alpha 61 - The latest patch has been much better, as the developer added a water pumping system and lots of QOF features.

However this game is not meant for the impatient types who want action all the time. If you learn the basics and watch some videos online, you will start enjoying this unique wilderness simulator called Subsistence!

As you progress through the game, you advance your cooking up to an electric stove, you also begin to get higher grade domesticated meat.  By mid game you are throwing extra food into the mass recycler because you have more than you can store in your fridge. The hunters (AI Humans) are in the game to make survival harder.  Subsistence is NOT a first person shooter, so the game is not designed for hunting humans for profit. Firstly, I have followed this game's development for the past 10 months by watching let's play videos of it by GameEdge on youtube. By just the changes you can see over those past 10 months, I can tell you this developer (a one man army) has been working his ass off.

On to the (partial) review.


1: The game is not only an Early Access game, but as far as EA goes, and the general life expectancy of the EA stage, it is in the infancy of EA. The base game is there. The mechanics are smooth. The graphics are impressive for a one man developed game on the Unreal Engine. New features are being added regularly, and game breaking bugs are being dealt with ASAP.

2: This game just came into public EA. Before now it was a private EA title. I can tell you that TONS of people have been begging for this game to reach public EA since let's plays of it first hit youtube.

3: Do not compare this game to Rust. Different engines, different mechanics, and an extremely different take on what Survival is supposed to be.

4: This game DOES NOT HOLD YOUR HAND. There are no tutorials. There is no "hints" system. You begin the game with a few basic things, like some water, some food, matches, a glow stick, and an axe. Any person that has even a smidgen of intelligence will now that the axe is likely used to chop wood from any of the trees in the game.

Honestly...."Survival" games from 2010-2014 have been pushing this whole mentality of hand-holding on the players. It dumbs down the games, and lowers expectations the players have.

Subsistence does not do this. You are not told what to do, where to go, or how to survive. You will be brutally murdered by a wolf or bear, or AI Hunter, at some point in this game. This is a fact.

If you are an intelligent person that's tired of having your hand held, then keep reading. Otherwise, GTFO and go back to 7D2D or Rust.



You chop wood. You run around and collect fiber from specific plants. You loot various resources ranging from building supplies to weapon supplies, food items, and medical supplies from "randomly" spawned crates.

These crates have different looks which tell you what they might have in them. The crates have a despawn timer. After a few minuets they will despawn, and randomly spawn somewhere else.

When you die, all your stuff is dropped in a small crate on the ground. If you have a proper base built, you can spawn at it and then run back to your crate. Otherwise you are spawned somewhere randomly in the map.

The crate you drop on death will only last for 5 minuets. This means you may or may not get back to your chest in time.


The Wolves and Bears are brutal. They are faster than you. They do more damage than you. They have more health than you. When they kill you, they level up. Increasing their health, and damage done. For most of your first few hours playing this game, you will either run away from each animal, or you will grow a pair, and shoot that level one wolf with 5 9mm bullets and kill him dead. Then you will cook his meat and eat it.


The base building in this game is on par with games like Ark, Empyrion, and Osiris. Look at youtube videos featuring building for this game for more details.

End of Review. I have only put 20 hours into the game so far. I still have plenty of things to do with base building, npc killing, animal hunting, farming, rasing chickens, and upgrading my guns.


Once I do all that, and put in another 20 or so hours, I will complete this review with a yes or no for recommendation.


If you are on the fence about whether or not you want to buy this fairly cheap, yet very polished for what it is EA game, go watch some old lets plays by GameEdge, then watch his newest videos for the game.

You will get both a sense of where the game started, how far it has come in a short time, and where it is headed. Go to the forums. Ask ColdGames any questions you might have. Either he or others in the community will answer them fairly quickly.

see alot of negative reviews from people complaining about the early game and how it's designed to kill you/impossible to live through etc. see a lot of youtubers that say to get used to dying early because it's just the way it is until you get set up.

...my usual strategy is moronically simple: spawn in, kill every tree i can, grab every box i see. if a predator is guarding a tree i don't need that tree. if a predator is guarding a box i walk into aggro range. if a predator aggro's onto you at their maximum detection range, they will start by walking towards you until they get close enough to become aggressive. the distance for aggression is about equivalent to 5 meters or so by eyeball. so for all the people complaining about unrealistic aggression, i'd say it's pretty fair that in a survival game where predators offer the only realistic challenge besides hunters, said predators can be easily avoided if your not an idiot. which is why i can get basically every box i see by just drawing them away and then circling back. 

once i have a few arrows and a bow, i make sure to kill every chicken i possibly can. 1 chicken gives 2 feathers which make 4 arrows. the return is ridiculous, the only problem is saving enough nails to build some shelter. RNG can tell me i'm not getting any nails. but i keep at it and they'll show up eventually. i usually have so much chicken it's spoiling in my inventory after being cooked, so i can sprint as much as i like which helps.

for my first night my objective is getting one foundation down, with one wall, and a ceiling. basically a lean-to. i put my fire inside it to protect it from the rain (like somebody with brain cells). i put a box down for storage. this requires about 80 wood, 50 nails, 16 fiber and 2 biofuel (for fire starting kits). this is perfectly within reason even if i've made more than 20 arrows on my first day (cause i'm not an idiot, and i learn how to play the game rather than expecting it to let me play however i like). 

by day 5 i'm usually up to medium clothing, over 40 animal fat stocked and needing a second storage chest to fit all my fruit/veg and seeds (i don't eat fruit/veg. not necessary, pure carnivore diet. the fruit/veg will go to my animal pen once i get one built). i usually wait to drop my BCU until i have over 100 animal fat, decent ore stocks and a single floor 3x3 house. once i drop my BCU my build order is Woodburner > Small Generator > Mass Fabricator. 

the woodburner is necessary for rendering my animal fat. the small generator comes before the mass fabricator because the woodburner offsets your power/mass ratio and i don't want to sit on max power waiting for max mass to build the fabricator. i still have to wait a bit for the mass to build back up, but once i have all three built i can just render fat into biofuel, crank biofuel into power and power into mass. with over 100 animal fat i have plenty of biofuel to accelerate my base building once i drop my BCU. after that... well, i've only had 6 runs. i'm working on figuring out cougars right now, so after one or two more runs i'll be farming sinew and have a working strat to reach endgame before day 10.

..i'm not some kind of god at the game. i don't even have 80 hours in (77 hours exactly as of writing this). the game isn't hard, it just doesn't pull punches. if you don't want to bother learning how to play the game, it WILL punish you for being arrogant or ignorant. honestly i love that aspect, it makes every death feel meaningful. "this is why i died. how do i avoid dying like that moving forward?" and there are usually MULTIPLE methods for dealing with every problem. the game isn't hard... it just expects you to deal with the challenges it poses rather than ignore them and charge forward recklessly. ...and once you learn how to deal with most of the early challenges you can certainly charge forward recklessly, as long as your not an idiot about it and know how to do it without getting wrecked.

i would certainly recommend this game to anyone who's looking for something different. it's simple and straightforward, but it won't just bend over for you. it's very different from most other survival games in that regard. the progression is a little overbalanced, but honestly the game would be crap if they went too far in the other direction and over tuned things too much. i hate to admit it, but the challenge and the intricacy it creates is 80% of the draw. get rid of that... and this game would just be another dime-a-dozen piece of indie-studio crap. 

if you want a game that empowers you as a player and makes you feel like an unstoppable force or a one man army... this isn't the game for you. if you want a game where every single step you take forward is a challenge, feels meaningful and provides a sense of accomplishment? i don't think i've ever found a better survival game.

At this point I've spent 17 hours playing this unforgiving game.

Sure, it needs work. It's an alpha.

The Good:
This is NOT a game you can "beat" easily or quickly. You WILL spend a lot of time wandering around, scavenging and chopping wood. You WILL spend nights huddled close to your fire and later wood heater. You WILL become a pro with a bow and arrow, or go hungry. You WILL celebrate each and every nail you find, early game.

The Bad:
The animals in this game as...brutal. And unrealistic. Wolves and bears are EVERYWHERE (far more than you'd ever expect) and will brutally murder you with every chance they get. You quickly learn to keep stamina handy for the many times you have to run for your life. Cougars are less frequent, but more deadly...yet plentiful in resource. Moose will straight up murder you if you don't kill them quickly. You'll get diseases from....everything. And they will kill you, keep a supply of antidote, splints and bandages on you at all times.

I do hope the animal system is fixed. There are far too many and they don't really hunt you or react to your presence in any way except aggression. They're just....there. More as an obstacle.

The scavenging system needs work. Some resources can only be had from the random bags of stuff lying around. Early game, they're everywhere. Later, they become scarce and you'll find yourself sprinting towards one you see on the horizon, in vain hope of finding a few bits of electronics. And scrap metal is even worse. Seemingly rare from bags, you'll celebrate every random pile of metal you find. Overall, I'm just not a fan of the scavenging system. However, it is an alpha.

PS - you get far more resources if you become adept at murdering hunters and rogues. Don't forget to raid their stashes and campfires. TAKE ALL THE THINGS MWHAHAHAHAHA.
But remember - they will seek revenge (if it is turned on).

This is not a 7 days to die type game. No zombies, duh, but also ammo is scarce and hard to manufacture. Keep your bullets and shells for hunters, rogues, deer/moose and emergencies. Wolves you can safely kill with a bit of dancing and your axe. Bears....leave alone unless you have plentiful ammo and/or like flirting with death.

Conclusion:
Overall, this is a good game. It is playable and enjoyable at this level of development, and seems to be getting regular updates. It has great potential - whilst frustrating and infuriating at times, you'll find yourself drawn back every damn time.

Everything there works and is well executed. The building and crafting environments are beautifully executed, the woodburner is the finest item of its type in any game I've seen, just stunning. TLDR: Love the Game. Worth it if you like survival games. 

Pros: 
-Hunt, gather, loot, and raid Hunters 
-Single player or co-op modes. 
-You can feel the difference between early, mid, and late game environment 
-Can disable Hunters or toggle how they interact with you if you want a more peaceful environment 
-Updates are consistent (map expansion, new items, etc.)
-Beautiful map/landscape 

Cons: 
-Combat/Hunting interactions are not smooth. You have to wait until the hunters stay still or an animal is running at you in a straight line to get a good shot. 
-Looting random boxes is a weird concept. Would like to see a system for looting that makes more sense, but have no current suggestion on how it can change

Things I would like to see in the future: 
- Rainwater collection 
- Water purifier machine (so that you don't always have to boil water) 
- More animals (wild/domesticated) 
- Animal breeding 
- Pets (dog, cat, etc.) that can help you hunt and can interact with
- Vehicles (ATV, Boats, Etc.)
- Sights/Attachments for Weapons 
- Rogues should be enemies with you AND Hunters (it would be fun to see them fighting in the distance and then you can join in the battle and collect the spoils of war!) 

Important Note: It is my understanding that this game was literally made and is maintained by one person, so ignore a lot of the negative reviews expecting it to be the exact same as a game with a ton of employees.

So far I've put just short of 40 hours in to this game and I've got to admit I've loved every minute of it. The gameplay is difficult but addictive and for an early access game there is more then enough to keep any hardcore survivor going for a very long time. As far as I know the game itself is being made by just one person and that fact alone knocks it up from a great game to an amazing game in my opinion. 

The hunting can be really hard for an early game character but it does seem to get easier as you put in the hours, I will just say to keep the hunters turned off till your base and character are well prepared to deal with their very annoying and damaging attacks. Also never waste your ammo on small animals, use your bow for them and just run if you see a bear or cougar or you will become an instant dinner. Wolves can be deadly but after a couple of ingame days you should be able to face them, even if you have a really bad aim like myself. 

As for food, keeping your vegies up is simple enough as long as you put in the time to get the berries till you find enough seeds to keep a nice planter fully stocked. Now meat is a different story completly, it spoils a little to quickly so I've found it best to cook and eat it as soon as you get it untill you can make a fridge. Also if you set up a base near water it's a good idea to build a little pier with a campfire to fish off at night, it can make keeping to a healthy diet a little easier if you can keep up with the need to find grubs (from the biggest trees). 

Now to the selling point of any game for me, the base building...............................The textures are fantastic and fit really well with the feel of the game but I do feel it is a tad expencive on resourses making the game really slow going for builders. So far the variety of things to build your base with is great, although I would like to see some railings to go up the stairs. Maybe a ladder and bridge type thing along with structural beems to add those all important finishing touches would be amazing and help with the creative side of building a base. So far I've not seen the option to build anything to help with defending your base which really does let the whole base set up down a little, more so if your going to be playing with hunters turned on while in singleplayer, so it would be nice to see that addressed in furture updates if possible. All that said I do really like the building options that are already in the game and look forward to seeing if this area will get a little extra love as the developer progresses with his no doubt already long list of things he's planning on adding and tweaking. 

Overall I am truly enjoying my experiance with this game and find it to be a refreshing change to the whole survival genre. It will be rather intresting to see just how the developer progresses with his already fantastic creation over time and I for one will be looking forward to future updates. 

Finally I would recommend this game to any and all survival gamers, it truly is worth it and whats more not a single zombie to be found :D :D :D

Absolutely fantastic job for a sole developer, well done!

This game is one of the hardest ones to survive [based on my personal experience], so the reasons of people hating [or just not liking] it are quite clear. 
- Every resource is scarce, every bullet is valuable, and punishing for each mistake is very painful.
- Getting resources (plus energy and base mass) for a device, upgrade, or sometimes even for a base bit, and finally installing it makes you feeling like a true hero.
- Killing a single predator is not that easy, and hunters are absolute kicka...s!
- Not to mention that hunting for particular resources, like sinew, is the whole quest itself...

BUT this is exactly what makes it different from all other survival games [based on my personal experience].
Here you have to learn how to survive step by step, each time paying a high price for your next piece of experience:
- How to move slowly and carefully, only allowing yourself to sprint rather short distances.
How to kill wolves and deers using just arrows, avoiding temptation to make it quick and lose a couple of bullets.
- How to use structures to hunt bears.
- How to keep your food indicators at not maximum, but rather sufficient, level.
- How to focus only on what's needed avoiding the rest...
- Well, eventually, how not to rush

Yes, slow, and yes, grinding, but all your efforts are rewarding at the end of the day.
Just learn how to play it instead of rushing, and you'll have a lot of fun!

A bit about other beautiful aspects:
- Lovely graphics
- Seasons changing, with not just the temperature and weather, but the overall landscape changes! I like that the developer is paying attention to small details
- Beautiful sky effects
- Winter fishing
...to cut it short, if you like the game, you will continue the list by yourself :)

(just for reference and fair judgement of the above, I played 7D2D, ARK, Empyrion, The Forest, Conan Exiles, Green Hell, Valheim)
